conformal mappings, harmonic functions

Let Ω={z∈C∣∣z∣>1 and Re⁡z>−2}\Omega = \set{z \in \C \mid \abs{z} > 1 \text{ and } \Re{z} > -2}Ω={z∈C∣∣z∣>1 and Rez>−2}. Suppose u ⁣:Ω‾→R\func{u}{\cl{\Omega}}{\R}u:Ω→R is bounded, continuous, and harmonic on Ω\OmegaΩ and also that u(z)=1u\p{z} = 1u(z)=1 when ∣z∣=1\abs{z} = 1∣z∣=1 and that u(z)=0u\p{z} = 0u(z)=0 when Re⁡z=−2\Re{z} = -2Rez=−2. Determine u(2)u\p{2}u(2).
Solution.

First, consider the conformal map z↦1zz \mapsto \frac{1}{z}z↦z1​. This fixes the unit circle, and it maps the line Re⁡z=−2\Re{z} = -2Rez=−2 to the line containing

−12,1−2+i=−2−i5,and1∞=0.-\frac{1}{2}, \quad \frac{1}{-2 + i} = \frac{-2 - i}{5}, \quad\text{and}\quad \frac{1}{\infty} = 0.−21​,−2+i1​=5−2−i​,and∞1​=0.

This is the circle centered at z=−14z = -\frac{1}{4}z=−41​ and with radius 14\frac{1}{4}41​. Thus, we have an annular region, but the circles are not concentric. To fix this, we will apply a Blaschke factor, which is a Möbius transformation fixing the unit disk of the form

φ(z)=z−α1−α‾z.\phi\p{z} = \frac{z - \alpha}{1 - \conj{\alpha}z}.φ(z)=1−αzz−α​.

By symmetry, we need to map −12↦−r-\frac{1}{2} \mapsto -r−21​↦−r and 0↦r0 \mapsto r0↦r, where r>0r > 0r>0 will be the radius of the resulting inner circle. We also expect α∈R\alpha \in \Rα∈R, so we get the system

φ(−12)=−12−α1+12α‾=−1−2α2+α=−r,φ(0)=−α=r.\begin{gathered} \phi\p{-\frac{1}{2}} = \frac{-\frac{1}{2} - \alpha}{1 + \frac{1}{2}\conj{\alpha}} = \frac{-1 - 2\alpha}{2 + \alpha} = -r, \\ \phi\p{0} = -\alpha = r. \end{gathered}φ(−21​)=1+21​α−21​−α​=2+α−1−2α​=−r,φ(0)=−α=r.​

Substituting, we get

−1−2α=α(2+α)  ⟹  4α+α2=−1  ⟹  α∈{−2−3,−2+3}.-1 - 2\alpha = \alpha\p{2 + \alpha} \implies 4\alpha + \alpha^2 = -1 \implies \alpha \in \set{-2 - \sqrt{3}, -2 + \sqrt{3}}.−1−2α=α(2+α)⟹4α+α2=−1⟹α∈{−2−3​,−2+3​}.

Since α∈D\alpha \in \Dα∈D, we see that α=−2+3\alpha = -2 + \sqrt{3}α=−2+3​ is the correct choice, and so φ\phiφ maps ∣z+14∣=14\abs{z + \frac{1}{4}} = \frac{1}{4}∣∣​z+41​∣∣​=41​ to the circle of radius 2−32 - \sqrt{3}2−3​ centered at the origin. From here, we see

v(z)=log⁡∣z∣/rlog⁡1/rv\p{z} = \frac{\log{\abs{z}}/r}{\log{1/r}}v(z)=log1/rlog∣z∣/r​

satisfies f(z)=0f\p{z} = 0f(z)=0 on the inner circle ∣z∣=r\abs{z} = r∣z∣=r and that f(z)=1f\p{z} = 1f(z)=1 on the unit circle. Thus, v(z)=u(1φ−1(z))v\p{z} = u\p{\frac{1}{\phi^{-1}\p{z}}}v(z)=u(φ−1(z)1​) on ∣z∣=r\abs{z} = r∣z∣=r and ∣z∣=1\abs{z} = 1∣z∣=1, so because these are both harmonic functions, we see that

u(z)=(v∘φ)(1z)=1log⁡1/rlog⁡ ∣1+rzrz+r2∣u\p{z} = \p{v \circ \phi}\p{\frac{1}{z}} = \frac{1}{\log{1/r}} \log\,\abs{\frac{1 + rz}{rz + r^2}}u(z)=(v∘φ)(z1​)=log1/r1​log∣∣​rz+r21+rz​∣∣​

which gives

u(2)=1log⁡1/rlog⁡ ∣1+2r2r+r2∣.u\p{2} = \frac{1}{\log{1/r}} \log\,\abs{\frac{1 + 2r}{2r + r^2}}.u(2)=log1/r1​log∣∣​2r+r21+2r​∣∣​.
